hackathon-judges.judge-role: Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
VP Research & Technology, National Center for State Courts
State Court Administrator, Supreme Court of Nevada

hackathon-eligibility: This is an in-person hackathon; all members of your team must be physically present at the hackathon venue in Salt Lake City in order to be considered for prizing. If you are not at least the age of legal majority, you must have written consent from your parent/guardian for claiming any travel-related prizes. There will be media and press crews at the event; participation requires consent to reasonable use for related promotional and marketing purposes.
hackathon-requirements:
You'll need to submit everything you developed and any other supplemental info you feel is important in a zipfile. Images of things really help (especially hardware!)
- team/project name
hackathon-rules:
Demos must be functional: no slideshows/pure design mockups.
Fresh code only. APIs and libraries are fine… but not if you wrote them. Winners may have code reviewed.
Teams can have up to 5 members.
Have excellent personal hygiene. ^_^
Be pleasant.
 
We reserve the right to eject anyone for violation of any of the rules above, especially #5. Just be sunshine and rainbows. Easy!
 
Note: there will likely be media at all the events, so if you’re not comfortable being on camera and having your likeness show up in noncommercial CourtHack videos, wear a large hat. <3 By participating and attending this event, you agree that images or video of you may be used in promotional and marketing materials related to the event and its producers and partners.

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Lunch with Utah Court CIO, Administrator, and Supreme Court Justice

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: $5500 cash and an expenses-paid trip to Las Vegas to demo at the e-Courts conference in December 2016
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Grand Prize + Presentation spot at the Vegas e-Courts conference Dec 2016
4-week mentoring program with One Legal incubator in San Francisco, housing provided for two

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=450 State Street, Salt Lake City, UT 84111, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: How will this improve the life of the beneficiary?
Think 'usability' - does this fit into people's lives, is it adoptable?
Can this team realistically pull off a deployment to the public/courts/etc?

hackathon-location-address: 450 State Street, Salt Lake City, UT 84111, USA
hackathon-description-header: Making justice fair and accessible for all
